label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, December 26, 1942
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, describing his Christmas, the gifts he had received, and the atmosphere of the office the day after Christmas.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
December 26, 1942
Sweet Eyes,
Just received your letter 42 of December 15th. It
was wonderful and I was so delighted to receive it, and to
hear all the news about yourself and th children. Miss
Charlotte is an amazing women and I re ly believe that she
will be responsible for Landine being a lovely person rather
than a problem child. Bo sounds beyondhelp like a naughty
puppy that everyone loves so much they efuse to discipline.
I wish I could see them both for a momnt, they have probably
changed enormously even during the shor time I have been away.
I opened my presents yesteray at two oclock. We
were given half the day off and str ke home like to excited
children to see what was under t ose woderful covers. You
are a darling to send me so many presens. The four leaf clover
[this dam machine just tore this when I threw the carri ge back]
was heaven. Your name and mine together with luck and happiness
is my one wish andto have it with me in your riting means it
will always come true. My present from Tanny was sweet, and
gave me quite a dig in the heart when I thought of him and his
big fat feet. I wonder if he was fed onlythe best steaks and
given a rubber bone[,]which in these times is practically like
solid gold and only percurable by a Vanderbilt. Then there
were so many choice tidbits. Crepe suzzettes in cans, baba Rhums
candies, sardines etc. that I will undoubtly become a gourment
and quite ill before they are all finished.
The box containing the stocking I took to the dinner
given by the two officers. I had just peeked into the top of
this stocking and found a bar of chocol te and some figs so
thought it was filled with these sort of things. It would
be fun to have the stocking at dinner and everyone could unwrapp
as having thought of bringing it to them. It went off as planned
until one officer let out a whoop and help up a tiny package
with a card on it. Everyone crowded around him and read in
loud voices "Merry Christmas to Daddy from Bo". After that there
was a mad scramble as we all dove into the stocking and emerged
with jams, [scratched through], a wonderful set of a bottle opener and cork
screw from Landine and all sorts of candies. No one would
believe that I had a child called Landine and they only knew
Bokara as a rug. It was great fun and added immensely to the
[End Page 1]
dinner.
The dinner was delicious, grapefruit, and then
a wonder ul twenty pound turkey cooked to a delicious goldnen
crispness replete with stuffing of nuts, mushrooms and marrons.
There were birds eye vegetables, asparagus and peas, which
made Morris very angry as he said though they were not strictly
fresh they were yet tainted with freshness and therefor were
not of the high quality possesed by c nned goods. Your two
plum puddings were e ten as desert and we poured rum around them
and set it on fire as we brought it into the dinning room.
Champagne corks flew with lous pops and Morris hit me in the
seat of the pants with one as I was stooping over to pick up
a fork. This was the high spot of his evening and his great
belly shoook with laughter for hours afterwards whenever he
remembered this coup. Finally at nine oclock we groaned home
but not before everyone had held forth on the war, women and
finance. A British Naval Officer dropped in and I was asked 
to interpret what he said as no one could understand him. They
said they could understand a little of what I said even with
my funny accent, and that I had had some experience with the
English and might be able to understand a little of the curious
language they spoke, and therefor could relay it to a third
manX who boasted he could could understand me f irly well and
would tell everyone else what was being discussed. This
complic ted system lasted only for a short time and broke
down very quickly as the arguments waxed hot. Knowing me
as you do you may rest assured that I retired very quickly
and stretched out in a chair to rest and recueperate my e ting
powers. You would certainly have gone to town and talked them
all down.
Everyone is back at the office looking as if
they should be under a doctors c re this morning and I am
afraid that the quality of work turned out xxxxxxxxxxxxxx
during these sad morning hours will not be of the highest.
I have not even a slip of aper to pretend ot be orking over
and then the captain passed on the way to his office I just
gave him a sad quiet look and laid my head back gently on the
des like a tired spaniel. Morris however is rushing round
pulling p pers out of the file and thre tening to start an
entirely new system which if put into effect will c use a
great deal of work and disrupt the tenor of office life for
at least a week. I suppose that empire builders are constructed
along these line but they should not be allowed to opetate
the day after christmas, the possible results are too serious.
Did you read the Furber book yousent me. It
is halarious. I read a chapter last night before going to sleep
it was about language books and the sentences they taught you
to use when you went to foreign countries. Every sencence was
based on diaster. You were only instructed how to say to the
chambermaid "the sheets are dirty", "there is a mouse in the
room". The sentences on air travel were only concerned with
"I am ill, give me a paper bag", The noise is dreadful".
all my love
Sidney Legendre
[End Page 2]
